>Does anyone think JUnit should give  some kind of warning
>when no assert* or fail is called in a test* method?

there are some cases when it's "ok" to have no assert* or fail. For example:

public void testMethod() {
      Obj.method("abc");  //test that it does not throw anything and accept
the param.
  }

this test fails only if method throws something, because we are testing it
should not throw anything and accept the value.
It's not a very usefull test but I do it from time to time. Some might argue
that it doesn't smell good that I'm not checking any post-condition but
sometimes there is none to check (method maybe does just plain nothing and
inhibits the call when a certain type of value is passed).

my 0.02$


----- Original Message -----
From: joelkevinjones
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 4:30 PM
Subject: [junit] Should JUnit determine if assert*/fail is called in
testFoo?


This semester I taught a class on Java programming and tried to
instill a little bit of JUnit into my students.  On their second
assignment, I had them write tests for the class they
implemented in their first assignment. (Yes, I know, that's not
test first...)  On the second assigment, I ran their unit tests
against my implementation of the first assignment's class.  I
used the text user interface as this made batching up the tests
easier.  However, on inspection of the student's code, I had
several students whose tests passed, but they didn't actually call
assert*() or fail().  For example:

public class MP0Test extends TestCase {
  ...
  public void testGetValue() {
      MP0class mp0 = readConfig();
       mp0.getValue() == 42;
  }
}

Does anyone think JUnit should give  some kind of warning
when no assert* or fail is called in a test* method?

Joel Jones
